title: These Boozy Cake Recipes Deliver an Added Splash of Elegance; From the new cookbook 'Gâteau,' these rum- and whiskey-laced cakes reveal what the French have always known: A splash of liquor makes a simple dessert sing.
text:
But then there are truly boozy cakes, generously brushed with a soaking syrup that is as much as half liqueur. The génoise, that classic French sponge cake intentionally baked dry, is built to absorb full shot glasses of spiked simple syrup. The result is spectacular. Gâteau de Nantes, a cake that hails from Brittany on the western coast of France and dates back to the early 18th century, remains very popular, and for good reason. It is brushed with a rum syrup and then also lightly blanketed in a rum glaze.

Speaking of rum, the baba au rhum is a cake quite literally doused in it. This recipe, too, was created in the 18th century, by the pastry chef Nicolas Stohrer. His employer, an exiled Polish king, had declared Stohrer's Alsatian kugelhopf dry. The king was so pleased when Stohrer returned, having brushed the brioche-like, sweet, yeasted bread with a reduced rum syrup, that he named the resulting cake after his favorite fictional character, Ali Baba. Today, the Stohrer Pâtisserie, founded in 1730, continues to draw Parisians and tourists in droves.

Clearly Stohrer was onto something. In researching my new cookbook, "Gâteau: The Surprising Simplicity of French Cakes" (Scribner), what struck me again and again was the gap between reality and myth. It's so tempting to assume the French are born with pastry-making superpowers but, by and large, they tend to cook and bake at home quite simply. Rare is the Parisian who returns home after a long day of work and makes intricate pâtisserie. They wisely leave that to the professionals. But equally rare is the Parisian who doesn't like to end a meal with a little something sweet. More often than not, this comes in the form of a cake that's taken no more than 10 minutes to mix and will be out of the oven by the time dinner is made and the table laid. The secret behind so many of these quick recipes is a liqueur, a spirit, a brandy. While this might seem lavish, it is, in fact, quite practical. What could be easier, and more effective, than adding a spoonful of liqueur to a bowl of batter?

For an average-size cake, adding a tablespoon of a brandy tends to add a subtle, sophisticated note. If you want the taste of the brandy to be a little more pronounced, double that, while three or four tablespoons will make a truly boozy cake. Sometimes you may simply want to augment another ingredient with a light hand. For example, a spoonful of Amaretto will further the taste of almonds in an almond cake, and limoncello will do the same for a lemon cake. Poire William, with its delicate fragrance of pears, boosts without overpowering, and it is delicious paired with chocolate. Even a supermarket pint of raspberries in the middle of winter will sing their very berry-ness if tossed in a little crème de framboise. But these liqueurs are best in small doses. You wouldn't want to drink a straight glass of crème de framboise, so it makes sense to add it to your batter sparingly. If going all in, brandy or a distilled liquor such as rum is the way to go, as it is unlikely you'll tire of the complexity.

If, however, you'd like to follow the Stohrer approach and brush a spiked simple syrup onto a baked cake, the rule of thumb is this: Choose a cake structured to absorb liquid without disintegrating. These tend to be sponge cakes or yeasted cakes. But a light approach with a soaking syrup—just a brushing really, with a silicone pastry brush—is something you can easily do to everything from yogurt cakes to Madeleines. What's wonderful about this technique is the immediacy. When baked, alcohol tends to become subtle; when added to a simple syrup, it keeps its punch. It's all a matter of preference.

The recipes included here use spirits in different ways. In one, raisins are soaked in rum before going into the batter of a classic French apple cake. In another, rum offers a layer of depth to a big cake, rich with autumnal notes. And the indulgent, underbaked chocolate cake, generously spiked with whiskey, is decidedly for adults only.
